Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the timeline of Ruth Bader Ginsburg's nomination and confirmation process by stating that it occurred 43 days before an election, when in fact it occurred more than three years before the next presidential election.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to back up the assertion that RBG was nominated and confirmed 43 days before an election.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the timing of RBG's nomination and confirmation is relevant to the current partisan battle over filling her seat on the Supreme Court.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim ignores the alternative explanation that RBG's nomination and confirmation occurred well in advance of any upcoming election and therefore should not be a factor in the current debate.
Contradict fact: The claim directly contradicts the fact that RBG was nominated and confirmed more than three years before the next presidential election.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the provided claim.
Falters at times: There is no evidence of the claim faltering or being inconsistent in its presentation.
